author: thehacktivist
content: Is there any better way to trace calls than using debug APIs of Ethereum ``debug_traceTransaction``?

author: sky.cactus
content: Nethermind and Besu support plugins.  I know Nethermind at least allows you to write plugins that extend the JSON-RPC and add custom behaviors, such as tracing like behaviors.

author: peter.davies
content:
Erigon has bunch of custom specialist RPC functions under the `trace_*` namespace (see https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/blob/devel/cmd/rpcdaemon/README.md#rpc-implementation-status) for a list. They were originally implemented by (the now defunct) Open Ethereum client.

You could also try playing with Foundry (https://book.getfoundry.sh/).  In particular, using `cast run` (https://book.getfoundry.sh/reference/cast/cast-run) will print a nice trace of a published transaction to your shell.

author: chris2_2_2
content: Just a suggestion but large Ethereum meetings should be restricted to countries and cities with a murder rate under x per 100,000. 20 would be a good number to aim under. Assuming an average lifespan of 70 years thats still more than a 1 in 100 chance you are murdered if you live in that country. If you have 10,000 attendees there for a 2 week period there's quite a high chance that 1 or more will be murdered.
